From ‘The Karate Kid’ to ‘Clueless,’ These Are the 25 New Additions to the National Film Registry. See the Full List Here
“The Incredibles,” “Inception” and “The Grand Budapest Hotel” join more than 900 titles preserved by the Library of Congress
Edna Mode, the brutally honest and beloved fashion designer from The Incredibles, once famously declared, “I never look back, darling! It distracts from the now.”
Mode can now rest assured that her own resonance is timeless, not only to audiences but also to the Library of Congress.
The Washington, D.C. institution, whose mission is to ensure the preservation of art and knowledge, included the 2004 animated superhero flick in the newest group of 25 movies added to the National Film Registry. The annual list aims to preserve a diverse collection of movies of “cultural, historic or aesthetic importance” for the enjoyment of future audiences.
“When we preserve films, we preserve American culture for generations to come. … Films are instrumental in capturing important parts of our nation’s story,” says Robert R. Newlen, the acting librarian of Congress, in a statement. “We are proud to continue this important work, adding a broad range of 25 films to the National Film Registry as a collective effort in the film community to protect our cinematic heritage.”
The diverse offerings in the 2025 class span 118 years, from The Tramp and the Dog (1896)—the first commercial film ever made in Chicago—to The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014). While working on The Grand Budapest Hotel, director Wes Anderson routinely consulted the Library of Congress’ archival images of Eastern Europe to create “visually striking stories and scenery,” according to the statement.
“When we were first starting to figure out how to tell this story, the views and images that we were looking for, the architecture and the landscapes that we wanted, they don’t exist anymore,” says Anderson in the statement. “We went through the entire Photochrom collection, which is a lot of images. We made our own versions of things, but much of what is in our film comes directly from that collection from the Library of Congress.”
Need to know: What is a photochrom?
- Photochroms are hand-tinted or painted prints of black-and-white glass negatives. Popular between the late 1880s and the end of World War I, these snapshots of landscapes and historic sites were similar to postcards.
- The Library of Congress’ Photochrom Print Collection showcases nearly 6,000 views of Europe and the Middle East and 500 views of North America.
The Karate Kid (1984), Philadelphia (1993), The Truman Show (1998) and Inception (2010) are among the highest-grossing films added to the registry this year. The list now includes 925 titles.
The Library of Congress’ preservation of roughly 25 films annually began after the passage of the 1988 National Film Preservation Act. The first films honored in 1989 included Hollywood classics such as The Wizard of Oz (1939), Citizen Kane (1941), Casablanca (1942) and Star Wars: Episode IV—A New Hope (1977).
Narrowing down a new class of films is a lengthy process. Experts from the library and the National Film Preservation Board suggested a range of picks for potential inclusion. Newlen, who made the final selections, also considered 7,559 films nominated by the public—around 700 more suggestions than were submitted last year, the New York Times’ Shivani Gonzalez reports.
The most-nominated film this year was The Thing (1982), a cult favorite science fiction and horror film that tells the story of researchers discovering extraterrestrial life in Antarctica. The Thing made it onto the final list of honorees.
Six silent films and four documentaries also joined the registry, including Brooklyn Bridge (1981), which tells the story of the New York City landmark’s construction and history. It was the directorial debut of Ken Burns, who has gone on to produce major documentary series about the American Revolution, the Holocaust and many other topics.
“This 60-minute film holds in it all the impulses that guide my own work internally,” Burns tells the Washington Post’s Sonia Rao. “It’s not a perfectionism, but just getting the facts right … and trying to make something whose whole is greater than the sum of its parts. To try to do something that could last and be beautiful.”
Denzel Washington and Bing Crosby were doubly honored in this year’s class of films. Each starred in two features added to the registry: Washington in Glory (1989) and Philadelphia (1993) and Crosby in White Christmas (1954) and High Society (1956), which also starred Frank Sinatra and Grace Kelly in her final performance before becoming the princess of Monaco.
These are the films selected for the 2025 National Film Registry, in chronological order:
The Tramp and the Dog (1896)
The Oath of the Sword (1914)
The Maid of McMillan (1916)
The Lady (1925)
Sparrows (1926)

articles.content:
When Vampire Bats Become Close Friends, They Start ‘Talking’ Like Each Other
New research shows that just like humans, vampire bats with deep social relationships use similar sounds as one another to communicate
Sometimes when people hang around one another long enough, they begin using the same slang, vocal inflections and pitch. Humans can pick up and mimic the sounds and words of the people around them, especially those with whom they have close personal relationships. But humans don’t have a unique claim on this kind of behavior, which is called vocal convergence. In fact, the same thing happens in many other species. For example, bottlenose dolphins that are socially close, like mothers and their calves, copy each other’s vocalizations. Elephants in the same social groups also make similar sounds.
Some bats demonstrate vocal convergence, but whether common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus) are among them was unclear. A new study, published in November in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B, now shows that vampire bats also make more similar vocalizations as their social connections grow tighter.
“Vocal communication in bats is something that we don’t know much about,” says the behavioral ecologist who led the study, Gerald G. Carter, of Princeton University, the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. “But we do know that we’re just seeing the tip of the iceberg, because bats in general have amazing vocal complexity.”
Vampire bats use some of that vocal complexity to hunt and feed every night, but contrary to the popular saying, bats aren’t blind. They can see, but they also have other strategies, such as echolocation, that help them find prey. Bats send out high-frequency ultrasound, or biosonar, waves, which bounce off objects and return to the bats to give them a detailed map of their surroundings.
Quick fact: More research on bats
For a new study published this month, the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute used a robot to mimic common big-eared bats’ echolocation skills.
But bats also like to chat with one another using chirps, trills and clicks. These lower-frequency contact calls can have many different purposes and can vary among different species and groups. “You can understand a lot about the social relationships and interactions between animals by examining the sounds they make,” Carter says.
Carter studies the social lives of vampire bats in Mexico and Central and South America. Through observing the animals’ behavior, researchers can analyze sounds in combination with visual cues and learn more about how mammals build lasting friendship networks.
Vampire bats are good subjects for these types of studies because they are highly social. They live in cooperative colonies of mostly unrelated individuals. These strangers start forming new relationships by first clumping together in groups for warmth. Then, a subset of the group will go a step further and groom one another. Carter notes that grooming is a way to test out a social relationship, because if another bat is receptive to being groomed, that could lead to a closer bond. An even smaller subset of bats, however, will share food. Bats must feed almost every night, but not all hunts are successful. If a bat is starving, another, socially close bat may regurgitate some blood and share it. Sometimes, these sharing bats are related, but not always.
As a graduate student, Carter started building a massive library of noises and vocalizations that bats make in different situations. After years of work, he believed that vocal convergence could be happening in the vampire bats he was studying. He found that a few bats he captured at different locations in the wild had different calls, and unrelated bats living together in a zoo colony sounded far more similar to one another.
In his most recent work, Carter and his team took the next step and analyzed the calls he had been collecting—almost 700,000 from 95 bats recorded between 2011 and 2019. “At some point, I realized that I was building up an amazing dataset, because we can look at similarities based on relatedness, based on how long the bats live together, and in a few cases, we had recordings of the same bats before and after they met each other,” says Carter. “We were able to measure and compare all of these different effects on the call similarity of the bats.” To record a bat’s calls, the researchers pulled it away from the group and put it in a tiny isolation booth with a microphone. The team initially found that calls were more similar among related vampire bats, but related bats also live together, so the cause of the similarity was unclear. Further evaluation showed that living in the same enclosure and being familiar with one another were the real reasons that calls were similar—time spent together explained call similarity regardless of genetic relatedness. For example, the vocalizations of unrelated bats, originally from different sites and later placed together in the same enclosure, became more alike.Overall, the most similar sounds developed from pairs of unrelated bats that shared food. Grooming, which is more widespread and less selective than food sharing, didn’t prompt bats to vocally converge as much.
“Even when these bats are all stuck in a cage together, they’re not all equally friendly with each other,” says Carter. “Each bat has its own network of relationships, and they have a subset of individuals that they have a really close relationship with.”
Gloriana Chaverri, a behavioral ecologist at the University of Costa Rica and a research associate at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute, who was not involved in the study, says, “What I found most interesting in the paper is the way that the researchers incorporate the ideas of how first joining a new group and then creating stronger social bonds—when bats are sharing food amongst themselves—changes the way bats communicate with each other.”
As with all studies, the research has led to more questions. Carter wonders how rapidly vocal convergence occurs between bats, and how precisely the sounds are converging. The similarities could be like accents or dialects, but they could also be akin to using the same words as the other individual or using different words at the same frequency or pitch.
And exactly why bats vocally converge is still unclear. Although they could just be making the same sounds coincidentally, or because they all feel hungry or sleepy at the same time, Carter doesn’t think that this is the case. The sounds likely mean something. “The variation in calls between groups might cause bats to know that a bat isn’t from around here, or that they’re from a different group,” he says. “From this study, it’s obvious that vocal convergence has some connection to the social relationships that we measure through grooming and food sharing, but we don’t know what the causal direction is.” In other words, do similar sounds develop from a close relationship, or do they help the relationship form in the first place?
Currently, Carter’s team is recording additional calls to see whether vampire bats are targeting them to the individuals that they have close relationships with, in either a grooming or food-sharing arrangement. Additionally, they’re testing whether bats use sounds like names for certain friends, which is called vocal labeling. “This is a bit controversial,” says Carter. “It seems like dolphins do this, because they’ll mimic the sound of another dolphin in order to address a specific dolphin, and so it might be that vampire bats are doing something like that, but we do not know yet.”
“We’re not the only mammal that needs social connection,” he says. “When you spend a lot of time watching them, you start seeing the personalities and all the ways the vampire bats communicate with each other, but there’s basically just this whole world of social sophistication and complexity that we are just beginning to see.”

Researchers Say This Paleolithic Teenage Boy Died a Slow Death After a Bear Mauled Him
A new analysis of “il Principe,” an ancient, decorated skeleton found in northwest Italy, confirms that the child died up to three days after being brutally attacked
Some 27,000 years ago, a 15-year-old boy went looking for food in what’s now northern Italy. It would be his last excursion. In the 1940s, archaeologists found the boy’s skeleton, battered and incomplete, in the Arene Candide Cave near Genoa.
Since the excavation, experts have guessed the boy—nicknamed “il Principe,” or “the Prince” for his lavish burial—suffered an animal attack. Now, researchers say they’ve confirmed the boy’s cause of death: He was mauled by a bear.
According to a study recently published in the Journal of Anthropological Sciences, the skeleton’s mutilations look like the work of a carnivore. Half the jawbone and half the left clavicle are missing; the remaining jawbone and shoulder are lesioned; the skull and neck are fractured; and the fibula has a puncture mark.
“Given the overall traumatic pattern, a bear attack … remains the most plausible explanation,” the researchers write. They posit the attacker was either a brown bear (Ursus arctos) or a now-extinct cave bear (Ursus spelaeus).
“We know that these people hunted bears, and that bears tend to avoid humans whenever they can, but a fortuitous encounter is still possible,” lead study author Vitale Stefano Sparacello, a biological anthropologist at the University of Cagliari in Italy, tells Live Science’s Kristina Killgrove.
Many bodies have been found in the Arene Candide Cave, which Upper Paleolithic hunter-gatherers used as a necropolis for thousands of years. The bones of the Prince, excavated in 1942, have been radiocarbon dated to between about 27,300 and 27,900 years ago—making his burial the cave’s oldest. According to the study, the boy’s body was laid in a bed of red ochre, clothed in a headdress made of deer teeth and hundreds of shells. Other grave goods included ivory pendants, carved antlers and a long flint blade.
“He was probably a budding hunter still learning his skills when [the attack] happened,” Sparacello tells Scientific American’s Sara Novak. Sparacello says that judging by the skeletal injuries, a mostly vegetarian bear likely saw the boy not as prey, but as a menace to dispatch.
Remarkably, the researchers think the Prince survived for two or three days after the attack. Sparacello and his coauthors examined microscopic evidence of healing on some of the damaged bones (first pointed out by other researchers in the 1980s). The healing abilities of these particular bones, as well as the speedy healing abilities of adolescents, suggest the boy’s body had begun to repair itself by the time he died—after either a long agony or long sleep.
“He probably lost consciousness during the event and never regained it,” Sparacello tells Live Science. “Most likely the adolescent was not alone because he was cared for immediately.”
The researchers write that given the violence of the bear attack, “it is surprising that this adolescent forager survived even for this brief time.” The animal must not have severed any of the boy’s major veins or arteries, leaving him to succumb to a “secondary brain injury, internal hemorrhage, or multiple organ failure.”
Quick fact: The cave bear's demise
- Cave bears went extinct about 20,000 years ago. A study published in the journal Scientific Reports in 2019 argues that human hunting and habitat encroachment, more so than climate change, led to the species' decline.
Though the Prince was only between 14 and 16 years old, he was likely an important member of his society, judging by his opulent grave. As Scientific American reports, it’s also possible the boy’s people took such care with his burial to prevent another evil event like the mauling.
Anthropologist Lawrence Straus, who wasn’t involved in the study but has researched other Paleolithic cave burials, tells Scientific American that the new findings illuminate the details of an ancient violence and its aftermath. “This is a glimpse into the humanity of those who lived during the last ice age,” he says.

Wild Jaguars Sometimes Meow Just Like House Cats, New Recordings Suggest. The Sounds May Help Mothers and Cubs Find One Another
Two female jaguars were recorded making meow-like vocalizations in Brazil—the first documented audio of the sounds in the wild
Jaguars are fearsome apex predators, capable of using their powerful jaws and brute strength to take down prey as large as caimans, deer and cattle. Yet new research suggests these fearsome felines might share a surprising similarity with their domesticated cousins: They meow.
Female jaguars were recorded making meow-like vocalizations in Brazil’s Iguaçu National Park—the first known audio of this sound captured in the wild. The discovery, described in a paper published in November in the journal Behaviour, adds to researchers’ understanding of how the big cats interact and communicate.
“Our results suggest that [jaguars’] vocal repertoire is more complex than what is described in the literature,” the study authors write in the paper.
Cats can make numerous noises—including powerful roars, rumbling growls, high-pitched shrieks and soft purrs—though their exact vocalization capabilities vary by genus and species. Scientists had previously observed meowing in some species of wild cats, but until now, they had only ever documented this behavior in captive animals. They had also heard stories from field workers about wild jaguars meowing, study co-author Marina Duarte, an ecologist at the University of Salford in England, tells BBC Wildlife Magazine’s James Fair.
Since 2018, jaguar conservationists have been conducting continuous wildlife monitoring within Iguaçu National Park, a 655-square-mile protected area in southern Brazil. The park is a UNESCO World Heritage site that shares a border with Iguazú National Park in Argentina. Together, the properties protect a large swath of the interior Atlantic Forest, as well as the various plants and animals that rely on the humid, rainforest ecosystem for survival.
The wildlife monitoring efforts, led by a group called Projeto Onças do Iguaçu, consist of 29 camera traps placed roughly a mile apart throughout the park. Every six seconds, the cameras record 15-second videos with sound.
When scientists analyzed the data, they were surprised to discover three clips recorded in 2022 and 2023 that contained unusual jaguar vocalizations. The sounds were high-pitched, sharp, brief and produced in a particular pattern—very similar to the meows uttered by domestic cats when they want to get their human owners’ attention.
Two of the clips featured an adult female that appeared to be searching for her cub, while the third captured a one-year-old female cub that was possibly looking for her mother.
The sample size is small, but the recordings hint that meowing might play a role in mother-young communication. If true, that finding wouldn’t be much of a surprise, since female house cats and their kittens also use meows to communicate. It also suggests that jaguars probably adapt their communication depending on the context.
The recordings reinforce the idea that “maternal care involves complex acoustic strategies that may be under-appreciated due to the difficulty of observing these animals in the wild,” Duarte tells BBC Wildlife Magazine.
Another possibility is that the females were using meows for reproductive purposes—to help them find mates, she notes in a statement.
At this point, researchers don’t know whether wild male jaguars also communicate with meows, but continued wildlife monitoring efforts could help them find out.
Such programs have led to other recent discoveries about the big cats. Last year, scientists described an adult jaguar in Brazil that apparently swam at least 0.79 miles—a record-breaking distance. Researchers don’t know why the creature paddled so far, but he may have been searching for a new place to hunt capybaras.
Together, the findings show that “even in one of the world’s most studied big cats, there are still intimate aspects of behavior waiting to be discovered,” Duarte tells BBC Wildlife Magazine.
